title: sun readers thank unsung heroes
story: MILLIONS of unsung heroes are doing their bit to help the nation battle through some of the toughest times we’ve faced.As part of our Hail Your Hero campaign, for the third week running The Sun on Sunday is printing your moving messages to the supermen and superwomen who are helping out across the UK.Today you, our readers, say thanks to YOUR unsung heroes who have stepped up – bringing aid, light and hope in these dficult weeks.Every single one of you mentioned here has made a real dference.We are immensely proud of you.I’D like to thank all the PRISON OFFICERS and STAFF who are currently working around the clock  hours a day, seven days a week, for the “forgotten prison service”. Prison officers are putting their lives at risk going into work every day during the Covid- pandemic. As a prison officer myself, I would like to thank all the officers across the UK as well as the colleagues I work with. So thank you to all the prison officers, prison staff, prison healthcare nurses and everyone  who is working the long hours to keep the prisoners safe during this time.TO my beautul and brave we KIRSTY ASTLEY, a nurse at St Helier Hospital in Sutton, Surrey. You’re an inspirational role model to our little boy Jack and we both admire your caring nature and bravery as you head off each day to look after others during these dficult times. Jack thinks you’re the best superhero ever and we love to you to the moon and back! All our love xxPLEASE acknowledge my amazing sister-in-law AOR BARBER. She is a key worker in a nursing home and cheers up all her “family residents”, researching dferent activities to keep them happy and distracted when family members can’t see their loved ones. She also takes photos and videos to send to the families so they know they are happy and safe. Even when her own two children had chickenpox she wouldn’t let them down. Aor is so dedicated and genuinely loves her extended family. I’d love itshe gets a mention here because is one in a billion and we, as her family, love her so very much.FIVE months ago my -year-old mother and I moved into DEIGHTON COURT CARE HOME in Walsall. It was the best thing we could ever have done. They are more like family than staff and carers – so loving and compassionate. They go out of their way to help us in every way and also help to keep our morale up. I don’t know how we can ever pay them back for putting their lives on the line for us butI find a way, I will. They so deserve recognition and praise.WE’D like to give our thanks to Solihull hospital – namely DR WILL and staff in AMU, all the staff on ward nine DR KHAN, ­SISTER ELAINE, NURSE RENNA, DOMESTIC ADEL and TRAINEE HANNAH to mention just a handful of the super team – we will never forget what you have done. Thank you. Please accept our undying gratitude for the care and support provided to Marc, who is severely disabled and was “on the brink” when he went into Solihull ­hospital on March  with le-threatening issues not related to Covid-. They even helped Marc celebrate his th birthday.THANKS to Yoga With TESSA in Caversham, Surrey, for your pregnancy yoga videos – from all your mums-to-be. When we can’t come to class it makes us still feel part of the group, as this is an anxious time for us all. So thank you for helping us to keep exercising.I WOULD like to thank each and every member of staff at PARK VIEW NURSING HOME in Blunsdon, Swindon, for coming to work and caring for the vulnerable residents including myself. Thank you.Stella Chapman SRNI VOLUNTEER for One Big Family Charity, run by LIZ and DARREN SHAW and loads of volunteers. We run a soup kitchen on Sundays in Chatham, Kent. We give out bags of cooked food, sandwiches and donated food to anyone who needs it. The charity also supports vulnerable people in the surrounding area by doing food parcels during the week. I just wanted to say a big thank you to all who volunteer for this brilliant charity.PLEASE, please, please tell my aunt HAILEY KIRK we are super-duper-proud of her working as a paramedic in Kent last week and this week. She’s done over  hours a week. We thank her and ALL NHS STAFF. All our love.THANK you to all the staff at UNIVERSITY COLLEGE HOSPITAL LONDON, many of whom have changed from their normal roles to be at the front line of the pandemic. Every one of you are heroes, along with your colleagues throughout the NHS.MY heroes are my daughter ANITA WALKER and my granddaughters MEGAN and MARTHA ELLIOTT who are all doing essential work. Anita works in a doctor’s surgery pharmacy, Megan as a member of the mental health crisis team at Harrogate Hospital and Martha at a school for vulnerable children. Martha hasn’t been required at her regular work, so has volunteered to work at a children’s hub looking after the children of key workers over Easter. I love you all and think you are doing a brilliant job. Thank you to all your ­colleagues as well and to ­everyone doing essential work.WELL done to NHS HERO ­SUPPORT, which got PPE equipment to University Hospital Lewisham, King’s College ­Hospital and St Mary’s Hospital, Paddington, as well as hospices and mental health centres. You’ve helped the lesavers giving it all on the front line. Thank you.MY daughter AIMEE HUNT is my unsung hero as she is just  and works as a domicillary carer in Whittlesey, Cambs, on minimum wage caring for vulnerable old people in the community.MY grandad JOHN BOWES has been working non-stop doing his deliveries and working super-hard. Please can we thank him. We love you, ­Grandad – keep on trucking xxxTHANKS to MELISSA MALLOWS who, along with a team of amazing volunteers, is getting help to where it is needed in Didcot, Oxon. They are ­making a huge dference and this is what ­community spirit is all about.THANK you to the amazing SAMARITANS team who are supporting people and being a voice on the end of a line through these dficult times. Unsung heroes alongside our NHS.I AM so proud of my granddaughter LAURYN, who is helping to fight coronavirus. She is working as a community carer in Sandwell, West Mids, and also as a bank nurse at Walsall Manor Hospital. Well done Lauryn – our prayers are with you.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here thesun whocareswinsappealPLEASE give a mention to all the BIRMINGHAM CITY COUNCIL CARETAKING STAFF who are looking after, cleaning, maintaining, removing rubbish and hazards and keeping the tenants safe in all of Birmingham’s tower blocks. Thanks to all of you for what you are doing.I WOULD like to nominate my husband, who works as a HGV driver and is part of the key workers team delivering food to Tesco. He is working so hard and his family are incredibly proud of him. Also, our son JORDAN COUGHLAN starts training soon as a firefighter. He will be a credit to the service. Again, we are so proud of him.TO my mother MAUREEN at  years young doing -hour shts in health care to help us get through this. You are a trooper. #healthcare #amazingTHANKS to the team at SOUTHMEAD HOSPITAL, Bristol, who are there for their patients despite the pandemic. To still be caring and patient when you are all facing so much is a ­testament to how remarkable you all are.WE would like to give huge thanks and love to my -year-old son BLAIZE, who while waiting to go to university has taken on extra shts at ­Sainsbury’s. When begged not to go, Blaize said: “Someone has to do it. If we all stop going, then what ” He’s right. We are so, so proud of you and love you more than any words can say.TO my darling daughter CHARLOTTE. Thank you for being so kind and understanding in these scary times. You are one in a million x. Love you so much xxLET’S have a big hand for our DELIVERY DRIVERS who are doing their bit to keep Britain going. My son Alex is one of them and they rarely get thanks for their efforts. So lets all give it to them.I WOULD like to thank my friend TINA and her husband STEVE. It has been really hard and her phone calls and texts have helped me and my family emotionally. They always put a smile on our faces. They are all stars with big hearts. Thank you for your support and friendship.THANKS to my wonderful we JACQUI WHINFIELD, who has been tirelessly working along with her colleagues who are making the parts which will help our NHS to save lives. Well done, love.MY partner of  years BETHAN FARMER is a care manager of an autistic children’s live-in care home. She works tirelessly, sometimes staying up working on her computer until am. We have a five-year-old daughter and with her working so much lately due to Covid- and staff absences, she doesn’t get to spend as much time with her as usual. Thank you to her – and all the care staff like her doing their bit.MY heroes are KIMBERLY and CHRISTOPHER GADD. They have been making sure my husband and I have everything we need. They have also kept their food business going delivering to all their customers. My other heroes are my daughters who are working on the frontline: JUNE FLETCHER , LISA FRAMEand TAMMY SMITH . All while telephoning  FaceTiming us to make sure we are safe and well.MY mum VAL HARDING works in Asda and she deals with customers who are sometimes rude and not following the rules. She’s my carer and looks after me, my sisters and my grandad who lives a bit away from us. But she still carries on. My mum deserves something special for herself. She is an amazing mum and person. I love her so much. So thank you mumsiee xxxI WANT to thank charity staff like SHELTER and SALVATION ARMY who are unsung heroes trying to help some of the most vulnerable people in society. It’s easy for people to forget there are people out there who have no home to shelter in during this time. Amazing people.WELL done and thanks to LOUISE and her PADIFOOT DOG WALKERS in Kent who are looking after all the key workers’ dogs. Amazing team – and they take away one of the worries while you are at work. Thank you very much.I WOULD like to nominate JOHN and JULES NATLACEN of village shop The Churchmouse in Barbon, Cumbria. From the moment the news broke that the virus had arrived in the UK, John and Jules were giving advice to their customers on how to stay safe and helping vulnerable people get deliveries. They have three children – William, aged , and eight-year-old twins Ava and Eliot – so not only do they have the responsibility of home schooling, they also have to look after them while they are looking after us. Heroes.THANKS to BRIDGNORTH MEDICAL CENTRE in Shrops. They have arranged for a team of volunteers to help their most vulnerable patients – going above and beyond but so appreciated.I’D like to take my hat off to every single NHS WORKER in our hospitals, GP surgeries and clinics who is still turning up for work in these uncertain times. Our NHS was always amazing – but I think perhaps for the first time, the whole country appreciates just how extraordinary every single person is who is such a vital piece of the machine. Totally amazing.I’D like to give thanks to my friend REMA. Thank you for being there for my nan when we couldn’t be. Knowing you are doing everything you can for her, while still being a key worker, makes being apart from her a little more bearable. You really are a wonderful person and I am honoured to be able to call you my friend. xxxThe team agreed to move in to look after the  residents, aged  to , after hearing of deaths from the virus of residents in care homes around the world.Diane said: “We just wanted to protect our residents. They are like family to us. While  of us stay permanently on site, the remaining staff outside bring prescriptions, do the shopping and drop it for us at the gate.“I can’t praise the staff enough. They are incredible and I’m extremely proud of them.”She added: “We hope it won’t be until Christmas but we know it will be at least three months.“We are doing what we can to keep everyone in touch with their families, using FaceTime and WhatsApp. We started by restricting visiting, with the support of the families of our residents, but when we heard about deaths of care-home residents around the world, including in Hove, it frightened us.“We had a meeting and decided we to do whatever it takes to protect those we care for. The thought of even one person getting it in the home was unthinkable. It doesn’t matter how much PPE you have, our residents are vulnerable. They all have health conditions.” Alongside Diana,  staff brought in suitcases, expecting to stay on site for at least three months.They are: Andrea Green, Susan Nolan, Susan Parkin, Wendy Knowles, Hazel Webster, Adela Tuhut, Vasillica Cazacu, Elsie Magayones, Shannon Roe, husband and we Lesley and Trevor Davies, Nicholas Layzell, Pin Burman and Robyn West.Many of her loyal staff have young families from whom they have been separated temporarily, as every member of the home self-isolates. Diana added “Elsie has a three-year-old who she has left with his dad to come and help here.“Robyn has a three-year-old daughter, while Andrea has a -year-old and my own youngest is . So we have all made sacrices but this is a matter of le and death.“This isn’t just a job to us. We think of the residents as being like our parents or grandparents. Staying put is the very least we could do for them.“We’re doing it because we love our residents. That’s the be-all and end-all of this. We aren’t doing it for any accolades.“We aren’t doing it for anything other than the fact that we care.”THANKS to ZANE POWLES who has been walking around five miles a day delivering school meals and homework to children across Grimsby, many of whom wouldn’t have a hot meal without his efforts. What a remarkable teacher – a profession that is often under-appreciated these days. Just amazing.SPARE a thought for all of the UNPAID CARERS – wives, husbands, children or relatives who are supporting vulnerable relatives. They deserve some recognition in these times for what they do.THANKS to BATTERSEA DOGS HOME STAFF doing their best caring for so many dogs waiting for their “for ever” homes. Hopefully the lockdown will end soon. You are amazing.BIG thanks to BRITISH GAS ENGINEERS who are going above and beyond their normal roles delivering food parcels to help local food banks and volunteering to get the food out to where it is desperately needed.Donna Lynn THANK you to KASIM ALI of WATERLOO TEA CAFE in Cardf and the amazing team of volunteers who have raised cash to give free food and drink to NHS workers.THANKS should go to ANDY BRELSFORD who has gathered together a tremendous group of volunteers who can help all across Cornwall, so people have somewhere to gothey need help. Every one who has volunteered in many ways across Britain deserves an award.I WOULD like to say well done to yoga teacher POLLY STANDEVEN, who has been giving classes online to keep people going and bring us a ray of positivity.THANKS to FELDY-ROO group, a group of businesses who are helping their community in Aberfeldy, Perthshire, with food deliveries. And thanks to their team of volunteers too.WELL done to RAJ ISLAM of Rose Of India, who is giving out free meals to NHS workers and police during the crisis.WE hear a lot about  crews but not so often about the FIREFIGHTERS who are also doing their bit during this pandemic. They are doing a tremendous job too.PLEASE give credit to SOUTH EAST CRAFTS CAUSES in Berkhamsted, Herts, whose , members are sewing scrubs and bags for hospital staff at the Luton and Dunstable University Hospital and Stoke Mandeville Hospital. Just goes to show that anyone can do their bit and make it count.CAN we remember our MILKMEN and MILKWOMEN – they are a leline to many of us in these times. Ours has been adding extras to make sure we have got what we need. I hope that people remember them when hopefully all this is over one day and they continue to give them their support.I’D like to say thank you to MARIE TAYLOR who is front-line with the NHS, selflessly supporting the local surgery in Sy, West Sussex. And to JOSEPH and SAM TAYLOR, who continue to go to school, even during the holidays. They also would like to say thank you to their mum. Not all heroes wear capes.TO all the front-line PRISON NURSES – especially at HMP EASTWOOD PARK, Gloucs, and to all the amazing PRISON OFFICERS who are constantly adapting their roles to keep our women happy and safe at such a frightening and uncertain time. I am so proud of all we do and so proud to be a prison nurse for HMP. And please also don’t forget the NURSING STUDENTS going on the front line without even finishing their degree in healthcare.WE are so proud of CHANTELLE LEANNE ALLEN nee JONES, and what you are doing, for your family and your country. Chantelle is a nurse, a new mum and recently married. She gave up the security of her home to serve, help and watch over the sickest ones in ICU. We’re in Oklahoma, in the US, and are so proud of our niece and her service to others. We love you.PLEASE can you give thanks to all of the dedicated EMERGENCY and NHS PHONE CALL HANDLERS answering ,  and  calls at this time. They are being forgotten but they are continuing to work in these extraordinary times and not getting recognition for their efforts.It led her to Carrots, who had been abandoned with injuries so severe his sight could not be saved. Since then, Katie and the three-year-old ginger moggie have visited hospices to offer comforting cuddles to patients.Katie said: “People always ask me how Carrots can see without eyes, and I say, ‘He doesn’t, he sees with his heart’.”Katie must self-isolate for  weeks as she is considered high-risk. But she was determined to continue the therapy sessions using video calls.She said: “Connecting to those patients in the hospice now is more valuable than ever – to feel alone when you’re terminally ill must be awful and I’ll do anything to share Carrots’ special warmth.”Katie – who also runs the Meowie Curie project to rehome pets of terminally-ill patients at a Marie Curie Hospice – has been sending cards to children’s hospitals on behalf of Carrots.She said: “Animals can be heroes just as much as humans.”TO my mum THERESA, thank you for those early rises and late finishes you do to ensure your staff and patients are safe. EvenI laugh at you trying to get up off the chair with your sore back! You still hobble to work with no complaints. Love.FAL PATEL has worked tirelessly to keep the relatively isolated East Sussex village of Plumpton Green supplied with food and news throughout this crisis. Thank you so much to Fal and the team at PLUMPTON GREEN VILLAGE STORE for risking their lives for us every day. From am, seven days a week, they have provided an absolute leline – especially to elderly villagers who would struggle to get to a supermarket. Thank you so much.HUGE thanks to my fabulous mum LESLEY MOORE who is a carer and dad STEPHEN MOORE and all of the other wonderful care workers for carrying on doing an amazing job. I have made a rainbow to show my support and have been clapping for you too. Best wishes, stay safe and thank you.A BIG thanks to EMMA and CHARLENE as every day we all sit at home with our kids keeping them safe. You both leave your children in the care of loved ones so you can go to work on the front line. You are both dedicated nurses fighting every day to help those not fit enough to do all their fighting alone. You are both heroes.I WOULD like to thank all those who work in the ENERGY, FARMING and LOGISTICS sectors and all the VOLUNTEERS who have stepped up and don’t get the recognition they deserve. They have put their lives on hold to keep the country going. It’s about time we all clapped for them too.MY mum KATHY VANGALIS is my hero. She could be enjoying her retirement but has carried on working at a pharmacy. She supports people who are struggling mentally and she always lends an ear and helps where she can. She’s my utter hero.THIS is for all the PHARMACISTS and the amazing ladies at ALCHEM PHARMACY, Thorne, Doncaster. They all go above and beyond the call of duty and are the friendliest people delivering medication to everyone at these very frightening times. They are a credit to our town.PLEASE can we say thanks to nurse AMANDA BUCKINGHAM of London. As well as being a fantastic single mum, she is going to work on the front line as a community nurse.TO LISA and the WOMEN’S AID LIVE CHAT TEAM, you are absolute heroes and are saving the lives of women and children every day by giving support to those living with abusers during the lockdown.THANK you to VIVIEN ACHESON, who works at Aldi Gillingham, serving the community with a smile. A fab friend.I would like my husband WAYNE LOONEY to be thanked as a hero. A neighbour shouted for help with her husband choking, so Wayne leapt into action and gave him emergency first aid. The paramedics said Wayne had saved the man’s le. He’ll for ever be our hero.TO RICHIE AITKEN, thank you for your kind words and being there. The hard times we’re going through will only make us stronger. I love you.I WOULD like to thank my daughter, JENNIFER HAYTON who epitomises the commitment of the Network Rail Track Team at Newcastle. Jenner is staying in a BB rather than commuting from home.I WAS shocked to hear about the deaths of so many BUS DRIVERS. Those who are going to be out there in the coming weeks, a big thank you. You too are doing an essential job to keep Britain going.A MASSIVE thank you to my very special mother-in-law DENISE FLEMING, who has helped raise hundreds of pounds to help me to cook comforting meals for our NHS staff at Broomfield Hospital in Chelmsford. She is fighting her own battle with secondary breast cancer but did not hesitate to show support when I told her I was doing a self-funded cook for our NHS heroes. Within  hours she helped raise £ for ingredients. A wonderful, generous, supportive hero.I’D like to hail my hero to my husband TONY GAUGHAN. He goes to work every day while I am at home looking after our two children. He buys the shopping and makes sure we have everything we need. He is our hero.I WOULD like to thank not just the NHS staff but all the bin men and women still taking our waste, LORRY DRIVERS keeping our supermarkets stocked, all SUPERMARKET STAFF having to take abuse from customers and all the FRONTLINE NHS STAFF working hard for the nation.THANKS to my good friend DAVINA BLACKWELL, who is still cooking at a special school in our area to make sure the children are fed and food hampers made up for pupils. Keep up the good work, Davina. Stay safe.WELL done to the pupils and staff at KENTS HILL PARK and OAKGROVE SCHOOLS in Milton Keynes, who have given thousands of items of PPE to a care home and health centre to help save lives.THANK you to our PARAMEDICS who really are on the front line, coming to the aid of so many. Thanks a million.THANKS to TONY CLARK for making face masks for the NHS. They are keeping us old dears going. She is truly a great colleague and my hero.I WOULD like to thank JONATHON BLACKBURN for disposing of people’s rubbish in the Walmley area of Birmingham. We all love and respect you more than you will ever know.ANNIE SAUNDERS is an unsung hero, looking after neighbours including doing their shopping and dog walking. She is an unsung hero!MY amazing we KELLY RYAN-JONES truly is a hero. She goes to work everyday in the care industry, where she puts her le at risk. We are all so proud of her.MY heroine is INDIA-THEIA McINERNEY, who is eight years old. DR TRACEY BELL has gone above and beyond, helping dozens of children and adults with dental problems. title: cabinet torn ending coronavirus lockdown
story: CABINET big guns are torn over how and when to end the lockdown now costing Britain £.billion a day.They are trapped in a “lives versus money” row with just  hours to go before the three-week restrictions ordered by Boris Johnson ends.Chancellor Rishi Sunak and Home Secretary Priti Patel are among those who fear the action to halt the spread of coronavirus is worse than the disease.They are pushing for a three-week extension, with an easing of restrictions as early as Monday May .But Health Secretary Matt Hancock and Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove warn this could end the treatment just as it starts to work.They want the lockdown in place for another six weeks from now, to be re-assessed on May  after the Whitsun weekend.A Cabinet source said: “It’s right and proper that we took action. But we must phase it out at the earliest opportunity.It could lead to many more deaths than the virus itself as the economy tanks, people lose jobs and families get poorer and sicker. We need a game plan for ending this.”Caretaker PM Dominic Raab can’t settle the dispute because his role is to chair meetings and carry out his boss’s orders.And with Boris Johnson likely to be away for another three weeks, the government is in danger of becoming rudderless.An insider said: “There’s a bit of a power vacuum. We’re in the middle of a global pandemic and we need him back — but he’s got to be left to rest and get well.”Education Secretary Gavin Williamson fears a longer schools closure will dash the le chances of poor and vulnerable kids.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealMinisters had planned for one in five pupils, the children of key workers, to stay in class yet only two per cent did so.And the Chancellor is shocked that his job retention scheme attracted nine million claims — three times more than he expected.The overall cost to the economy will be nudging £billion by the end of the long Easter weekend.Eventhey agree a date, ministers still have to work out how far to go in ing Britain to normal.Medics and scientists warn that a swtcould lead to a second wave of the virus, with an even more devastating effect.One option is to lt restrictions on dferent regions or sectors. Some are pushing for young people — less prone to serious illness from the virus — toto work first.But a sceptic remarked: “It’s the over-s with the money and experience who are the wealth creators. We need them back soon.”Without a game plan, there are fears that tough limits could still be in place this time next year.The First Secretary of State, Dominic Raab, has rightly said that there is a huge team spirit behind the Prime Minister, willing him on to get back to full health and back where he rightly belongs – leading the Government and our country from  Downing Street.It is important that the business of Government continues at pace during the Prime Minister’s temporary absence from the Downing Street tiller, eventhat is for some time. Decisions, even signicant and dficult decisions, must still be taken by the Cabinet as and when necessary.In this country, we have a system of Government where key decisions are taken by the Cabinet. It is, of course, true that the Prime Minister has signicant personal authority, especially where there is disagreement.However, while the Prime Minister is out of action, his authority will be exercised by Dominic Raab, the First Secretary of State, because he is the Prime Minister’s chosen deputy.Ministers, I am sure, will be very conscious of the fact that it was the Prime Minister who made that choice and he will expect it to be respected. I am sure the Prime Minister will not be amused to read about what has been going on in Cabinet committees in his Sunday newspapers.When the Prime Minister announced the current restrictions on  March, he said this would be reviewed after three weeks. The time for this review is next week.Given we are yet to reach the peak of the virus, I am quite sure that next week the Government will formally decide that the current restrictions will have to stay in place for another three weeks into May.The data on the number of new cases is starting to suggest that the current social distancing measures are working but continuing with them for another period is necessary to ensure we protect the NHS and save lives.That’s why people need to continue to stay at home over the Easter weekend, apart from the four allowed exceptions. Thinking about the future, we will only be able toto something like normal le once we have created a vaccine.This is likely to take somewhere between - months and so, in the meantime, we will need a recovery plan that continues to protect the health of the nation whilst allowing us to get the economy going again.The Government must work on that recovery plan at pace whilst it continues with the current restrictions and it must also be as open as possible with the public about what that plan will look like as and when the pieces are put into place. There are three reasons for this.First, whilst the vast majority of the population has been doing a fantastic job complying with the rules so far, the longer the restrictions are in place, the more likely we are to continue this level of compliancethe public can see the light at the end of the tunnel.Second, over the coming days and weeks, the many people in our country who are self-employed or who run larger companies are going to need to take decisions about the future of their businesses.So we need to give them as much information as we can, as soon as we can, about the future so they are prepared to take the calculated risks necessary to keep their businesses going. That’s vitally importantwe’re going to minimise the economic cost of defeating this virus.Finally, any recovery plan is likely to involve a signicant volume of testing, with contact tracing and perhaps the use of technology seen in countries like South Korea to ensure any resurgence of virus can be dealt with swtly.As we have seen from the challenges facing the Government on testing for NHS frontline staff, it takes time to get this capacity in place.We need to make sure than when the Government is confident that the evidence is in place to allow a relaxation of the current measures, our testing capability, and all that goes with it, is ready to be rolled out quickly.I am confident that the Cabinet, led by the First Secretary of State Dominic Raab in the Prime Minister’s absence, will continue working hard and making the necessary decisions when they need to be made so that the PM, upon histo health, can hit the ground running and, as the Prime Minister’s great hero Sir Winston Churchill would say, take “action this day”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain pay as you go brexit deal
story: Ministers have refused to extend the transition period by two years and want month-by-month membership until an agreement has been reached.It would avoid paying billions to stay in the single market and keeping the UK tied to European law until the end of . PM Boris Johnson had it written into law that Britain would leave after December , with or without a deal.A source said: “We’re determined to keep our promise.“There is no way we will commit to a long extension. But in case extra time is needed, we’ve offered to renew the period for a month at a time until the deal is signed and sealed.”With Europe in lockdown, EU chiefs say thinking a deal can be done is “fantasy land”.The HQ where officials co- ordinate negotiations is doing only a quarter of normal work.EU chiefs insist they must know by JuneBritain is to seek an extension. Politicians on both sides fear cutting ties without a deal will deepen the chaos caused by Covid-, which has cost the UK an estimated £billion so far.With extensions into  one month at a time, Britain would pay a proportion of an annual fee to keep trade barriers up.The source said: “We want to avoid any further turbulence on both sides of the Channel — but we’re clear Britain has left.”Belgian MEP Kris Peeters said: “You do have to questionit is possible to reach a deal by the end of this year.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Shadow Secretary of State for Health and Social Care Jonathan Ashworth criticised the sincerity of the apology. He was asked on Sky News: “Shesaid she’s sorry, is that good enough ” to which Ashworth replied: “No, I mean it wasn’t really an apology was it  It was one of those half-hearted apologies where you use the word sorry to give the impression that you apologised, but you’re not actually in reality apologising.  “We’ve had the doctor’s bodes, the nurses bodies, we hear stories everyday of healthcare workers on the front line forced to cut up curtains to make their own PPE, we’ve heard stories of nurses in bin liners because they couldn’t get PPE, and those nurses have now come down with coronavirus. This has been unacceptable. It has not been good enough.” It comes after Health Secretary Matt Hancock revealed today that  NHS workers had died during the coronavirus outbreak. The Government has been slammed for not providing health workers with enough personal protective equipment, putting their lives at risk as they treat patients infected with the virus.  Dr Rinesh Parmar, chair of the Doctorsapos Association, previously said some of his members felt like aposlambs to the slaughterapos and aposcannon fodderapos because of the lack of proper clothing. The Mirror revealed how some medics were so desperate for protection they cut up hospital curtains to use as gowns. NHS worker Thomas Harvey, who  caring for a coronavirus patient at Londonaposs Goodmayes Hospital but did not have any PPE, died after reportedly catching the disease.  The dad-of-seven passed away in self-isolation at home and police officers had to break down a door to retrieve his body. The -year-old had spent weeks fighting for his le after developing symptoms including a cough, shortness of breath, weakness, and aches and pains all over his body. He wasnapost given personal protective equipmentsuch as a mask at work, and he didnapost knowhe was infected with coronavirus because he wasnapost given a test, claims longtime friend and colleague of his who did not wish to be named.

title: voice people you flout coronavirus
story: NewsopinionVoice of the People: If you flout coronavirus lockdown youre traitor to national causeThank you to everyone who has stayed indoors despite the glorious Easter weekend weather - butyou flouted rules, you are a traitor to this country and our NHSShareCommentsByVoice of the People:,  APR NewsopinionSocial distancing isnt fun, but it is so important " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCongratulations and thanks to all those who are following social distancing rules this weekend. It is not easy to stop at home when we are blessed with the rare treat in Britain of glorious weather at Easter. You are not only saluting the heroic efforts of NHS staff on the frontline but also joining in the national fight against an invisible enemy with more destructive potential than any the world has ever faced. If you are among the selfish minority flouting the rules there is, bluntly, only one thing we can say. You should be condemned as traitors to the national cause. We are all keen for the lockdown to be over. But impatience will not make the virus go away. A clear, coherent exit strategy is needed. Both to suppress the spread of the virus and to map a way out of the crisis. We are, on the whole, heeding the government advice on social distancing. That is the first step. The advice is right, and there are the first glimmers that it may be working. But that will not, in itself, show us the way out of lockdown. And any premature lting of the restrictions will risk a deadly second wave. It pains us to criticise the Government at a time of crisis. But failures are becoming clear and, without wishing to score any political points, justiable questions need to be asked. Was the Government too slow to act on supplies of masks, gloves, gowns and ventilators  Has it been truthful about shortages  Or even about the death rates, which do not include the tragic figures from care homes  Questions for a future inquiry. Now ministers need to show us what is being done to lead us to an effective and safe exit.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt was on a trip to India that Nav Sawhney was first inspired to come up with a creation to help women in poverty.The -year-old engineering student was on a placement in the rural village of Kallipalayam, which had limited access to water and electricity. Every day he would pass his next-door neighbour Divya, and see her hunched over a bucket, scrubbing clothes. ‘I walked past this woman’s house every day, and every day she was washing clothes,’ Nav says. ‘We got chatting and she told me how her back hurt and she showed me the rash on her hands. I thought there must be something I could do, and set my mind to finding a solution.’ A modern washing machine was out of the question for Divya, , who does not have regular electricity, so Nav knew he’d have to be creative. He says, ‘Seventy per cent of the world’s population doesn’t have access to an electric washing machine… I realisedI could make a low-cost washing machine for Divya, which she could operate by turning a crank, it would save her so much time. That’s time that could be spent pursuing an education or paid work.’ Divya became a good friend of Nav’s while he was in the village, and she was over the moon when he told her his plan. ‘Her eyes lit up,’ he says. She loved it.’ Watching the mum-of-two struggling reminded Nav of his own childhood growing up in London. Nav’s dad Avtar died suddenly from heart failure when Nav was eight, leaving his mum Mohini, now , to care for three young children. ‘I remember Mum toiling away all day,’ he recalls. ‘As soon as she came home from her job in the civil service, there was cooking, cleaning and laundry to do. My siblings and I would try and help out around the house, but we were only young.’  Nav had always had an inquisitive mind and, growing up, he would take kitchen appliances apart and try to put them back together again. ‘Dad was an engineer too, and he’d encourage me to figure out how things worked,’ he remembers. ‘It would drive Mum nuts, but I was fascinated by the mechanics behind the gadgets.’ Nav went on to study engineering at Queen Mary University of London, and later joined Engineers Without Borders UK, which encourages people to find solutions to the hardships of people all around the world. It was through Engineers Without Borders that he met Divya and came up with the idea of building the hand-crank washing machine. He formed a team of specialists and put his head together with fellow engineers, anthropologists and data scientists, and they created a prototype. The prototype was then trialled at the Response Innovation Lab in Iraq, led by Oxfam, which provides funding for new innovations that improve poor people’s lives.  In , as part of his research for the washing machine, Nav visited Iraq and met families living in camps in Iraqi Kurdistan in the north of the country. ‘People have been through so much hardship,’ he says. ‘I sat with families in their tents and often there was a father or a brother or an uncle missing, taken away by ISIS and never seen again.’ Nav spent time learning what families’ needs were, and carried out research which showed that women were spending as long as  hours a week washing clothes. ‘The average size of a family in a camp is nine, with half being under the age of five – so lots of dirty clothes, lots of washing to be done. We took this all into account people wanted drums with a bigger capacity and they didn’t want to bend down. They didn’t want interaction with soap because it caused rashes. They wanted it to be light and portable. We incorporated all that into our design.’  Nav and his team created a washing machine from wood and plastic costing just £. The machine, which Nav named after Divya, has a drum capacity of kg but only uses  litres of water per cycle, as opposed to the  litres used by the average electric washing machine. ‘We believe that using the washing machine, women could wash the same amount of clothes in  minutes instead of  hours! Can you imagineyou gave back  hours to Divya, what she could do with her time  She could have the power to do whatever she wants,’ he says. In February,  washing machines were distributed by Oxfam to refugee camps in Mosul as a pilot project. ‘I think the burden placed on women is so unfair, so seeing that first-hand at home with Mum and then trying to be able to equalise that in some way is something I’m really passionate about.  aposMy mother is really proud of me, she’s my biggest supporter. She is what drives me. I see her struggles in other women’s struggles.’ And Nav’s dad, who was an engineer, would have been proud too. ‘During the Partition of India in , he became a refugee after fleeing his home with nothing but the clothes on his back. It’s up to us to help people along the journey and the refugees that I’ve met in Iraq have had it the worst. aposUnimaginable things have happened to them, things that are really hard to fathom. Becoming a refugee can happen to anyone,’ he says. ‘We’re put on this planet for a short period of time, and our impact on other people’s lives is what matters the most. It’s up to everyone around the world to help.’

title: mum shares coronavirus cooking tips
story: NewsMum shares coronavirus cooking tips after feeding family-of-four on WW rationsAs coronavirus makes us obsess about food stockpiling, Claud Fullwood explains what it was like to live on Second World War rations for Lent with her young familyShareCommentsByChristine Smith:,  APR NewsClaud Fullwood makes a box of food like this last all week " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMum Claud Fullwood, , who lives with her husband Ben, her -year-old stepdaughter and her three-year-old son, challenged herself to live off World War II rations for Lent. In her own words she tells us how she managed to do it... I was working on a hunger campaign for CAFOD, a religious charity, and I wanted to do something to help. I’d also been watching a wartime farm TV programme and, mindful that there were so many food shortages around the world, the idea came to me to live off Second World War rations for Lent, rather than simply giving up chocolate, as I do every year. The war rations were basic – British seasonal vegetables, fruit, potatoes and bread , as well as fish . A set number of rationed items – like g of meat per week – were also included. And people were given  points a month on top of that to buy other items, including tinned tomatoes. I knew it was going to be tough, but I was determined to complete it. I decided the first thing I would do was start up a blog and invite everyone to share their ideas. I also reached out to family members who had lived through the war to hear their stories and the importance of stretching everything out. Like most of us in the modern day, I’d grown very used to the fact food was available  . I was on a good salary in London and I tended to pick up a bacon sandwich at the station for breakfast, and I’d either have a meal with work colleagues or grab a baguette for lunch. If ever I ran out of anything at home, I knew I could pop out to get the ingredients.  Potatoes were plentul in the wartime rations and I knew I would have to incorporate them a lot in my own food plan. And so for breakfast I’d either have fadgeor porridge mixed with water. Lunch was homemade vegetable soup – obviously including potatoes – or a small amount of cheese, which I’d grate onto soda bread I’d make using a recipe given to me by my lovely gran. For dinner, I’d have a stew, pasty or shepherd’s pie packed with vegetables, a tiny bit of meat and more potatoes. In February March, there are a lot of root vegetables around, but not many juicy fruits like oranges, so I just used to eat apples as a snack or dessert. It was also important that I stuck to the strict rules of only eating British seasonal fruit, given that is what would have been available in the war. Breakfast Irish potato cake or porridge Lunch Soda bread with a bit of cheese or homemade vegetable soup Dinner Meat and vegetable stew, homity pie or shepherd’s pie Snacks dessert Apples Ration tips to make your meals go further – Grate cheese onto a sandwich rather than cutting it – Use a non-stick pan to avoid using lots of oil– Don’t use meat and cheese in the same dish– Make stock from your chicken carcass– Make potato rosti from uneaten roast potatoes– Never throw any leftover food away. You can always add a fresh ingredient the next day Week two also went OK, but by the halfway point everything was starting to get boring and repetitive. The war rations were nutritional, but very samey and I got sick of the sight of potatoes – something I never thought would happen. And I wish I’d known more about seasonal eating. There’s actually a lot of food available, even in the winter, which I just wasn’t aware of. One of my lowest points was when I just couldn’t face dinner one evening. I’d spent my points on a tin of Spam, which was  points. The whole point of the challenge was to not waste food, but I simply couldn’t face eating it! Thankfully, I had just enough points left to get some raisins instead, but I felt very flat. There were other times when I couldn’t face eating the same meal – and that was a challenge, along with issues like not planning properly and running out of things.  I also found socialising and eating out limiting. I only went out twice over the whole period and I had fish and chips on each occasion, as it was the only meal I could think of that guaranteed I wasn’t cheating! But that said, people were very kind and they would meet me for a cup of tea instead of a drink after work, or we would take our lunch and eat it outside, or they’d come to my house. People did still drink in the war, so I was sensible and had one each time I went out to eat. A gin and tonic. The foods I missed most were eggs and oranges. I avoided making desserts, as I didn’t know what to make without eggs. I also found myself longing for something juicy, so I really found it dficult not being able to have any citrus fruit. Bizarrely, despite being bored I felt healthy. It was all aimed to be nutritional. For an average, non-pregnant adult, the weekly rationed foods in  were:  pints of milk g meat, -g cheeseg bacon ham g tea g sugar g butter g cooking fat Plus  egg per month Non-rationed foods Vegetables, bread, oats, pearl barley, wheat, rye, fish Points system food Other food was rationed on a points system, subject to availability. Adults received  points a month for these foods : – British tinned fruit  points per g – Cereals  points per lb – Crackers  points per lb – Dried fruit  points per lb – Rice pasta  points per lb – Tinned tomatoes  points per lb Weirdly, I found the food I had the most of at the end of each week was sugar. I didn’t bake, and I only used a bit on porridge. As the challenge drew to an end, although I was very bored of eating the same food over and over, it felt amazing to know I’d managed to stick to the challenge for  days. I’d also lost about half a stone in the process. To celebrate on Easter Sunday, the first thing I did was tuck into eggs and oranges! I wasn’t interested in chocolate at all. The experience was an inspiring one. Not only did it open up so many new connections with amazing people who offered tips along the way, but I also learnt so much. It taught me how wasteful I’d been, and I became a lot more conscious of what I was throwing away and putting in the shopping trolley. It taught me how to rotate my fridge to make sure I used the food that was going out of date first, and to not always go by the sell-by date.  You can’t mess around with chicken or prawns, but you can look at your potatoes or carrots to seethey have gone off, rather than going by labels. The lasting effect of the challenge has been that we now live off a third of what we used to and we’ve continued to use many of the tricks I learnt. We have potluck dinners at the end of the week where we eat whatever is in the fridge, and we’ll adapt a recipewe don’t have everything we need in the cupboard. Not surprisingly, these tricks have proved very useful over the last few weeks during the lockdown. And just like the rations, it is about being adaptable.

title: brave bride speaks out after
story: NewsBrave bride-to-be speaks out after abusive ex attacked her before their weddingBecky Aitken required stitches to her cheek after her ex-fiancee viciously attacked her at home like a "raging bull" months before they were due to tie the knot - hes now been jailedShareCommentsBySophie Corcoran:,  APR NewsBecky was viciously attacked " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA brave bride-to-be has spoken out after her abusive ex fiancé viciously attacked her just months before the wedding. Becky Aitken was due to tie the knot this month but says her ex partner will now be “rotting in jail where he belongs” after he pushed her into a bath and threw an ashtray at her head.The -year-old was left needing stitches to her face after the brutal assault by her ex Lee Mulligan, reports Hull Live.Mulligan, , of Rhodena Avenue, Bridlington, was jailed last month at Hull Crown Court. Becky, who is from east Yorkshire, said the attack happened last November because she was late getting home from his mother’s house.  The mum-of-three said: “It was horric. He was like a raging bull. Lee was asleep on the couch when I got in but as soon as I walked into the living room, he started on me, demanding to know where Iaposd been. “I ran from room to room, but he followed me, hitting and punching me as I ran. Then he threw me across the landing so hard, I fell into the bath with him towering over me. I donapost know how, but I managed to break free and run downstairs. I saw him throw the big heavy ashtray through the air. It hit me in the face and knocked me off my feet.  After the attack Becky sought solace with a neighbour who called the police. Becky became engaged to Lee in September. She said Lee had started to become controlling and possessive shortly into their relationship, which began three years ago. Lee would commentI was a few minutes late back from visiting my pals,” she added. He even questioned me after Iaposd been to the supermarket. I felt like I had to account for my whereabouts every day. At first, I was flattered that he wanted to be with me constantly. I thought maybe he was a bit insecure. I was in no doubt that he loved me. I loved him, so I put up with him being possessive, and of course we had plenty of good times too. She now says she wants nothing to do with her ex-partner. During the court case, Clare Holmes, representing Mulligan said the couple had reunited and were planning to marry this month – but Becky says this is . Mulligan’s defence also relied heavily on the fact Becky did not complete a victim personal statement.  She said she did not complete one because she was frightened by the repercussions. Judge John Thackray said that just because there was no victim personal statement, it did not mean Mulligan should get a suspended sentence. He told Mulligan: Let me make it clear that your offending is not less serious because it is in a domestic setting. There is a breach of trust in that element and a vulnerability in her.

title: calls coronavirus levy google facebook
story: NewsCalls for coronavirus levy as Google and Facebook accused of avoiding billions in taxEXCLUSIVE: Campaigners demand international companies such as Google and Facebook help fund crippling cost of lockdown instead of low-paid workers such as NHS staffShareCommentsByAlan Selby:,  APR NewsCampaigners want global tech firms to help fund crippling cost of lockdown, instead of low-paid workers " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCampaigners have called for a coronavirus levy on the household name tech giants accused of­ avoiding at least £.billion in tax. The Fair Tax Mark wants a ­dramatic change in taxation so that international companies help fund the crippling cost of the lockdown in Britain – instead of lowly-paid workers like NHS staff.The demand come just weeks after five tech giants – including Google – were accused of avoiding tax worth an estimated £.billion in the UK last year. Paul Monaghan, chief executive of Fair Tax Mark, said: “Silicon Valley mega-corporations such as Apple, Facebook and Google should be forced, at last, to make a fair tax contribution to the public services on which they rely, just like the rest of us. “No public money, be that ­ coronavirus bailouts or public ­procurement contracts, should go toward businesses that refuse to sign a Fair Tax Lockdown pledge.“This would entail a binding public commitment from them to shun tax avoidance and tax havens.” The call was backed by Labour’s new shadow chancellor Anneliese Dodds, who said: “At a time when so many people are seeing income plummet, many tech companies are ­experiencing a boom. “It’s more important than ever they are paying their fair share of tax. Labour will continue to push the Government to help secure vital funding for our NHS and public services at this critical time.” Britain’s economy is predicted to shrink by - per cent between this month and June. And the cost to the taxpayer of the job retention scheme has been estimated at £- billion over the three months. Meanwhile Apple, Google, Cisco, Facebook and Microsoft raked in a combined profit of £.billion in Britain in , think-tank Tax Watch UK said in February.  But it claimed they used complex financial structures to take profits offshore and pay a fraction of the tax they should have handed over. Their UK corporation tax totalled £million in  – an effective tax rate of just . per cent. Tax Watch estimates Apple avoided a ­£million bill, Google £million, Facebook £million, Microsoft £million and Cisco £million. In the UK, Facebook paid just £.million in corporation tax in  despite a record £.billion in British sales. This week it emerged Google paid £million in UK ­corporation tax in the last year – ­despite £.billion in revenues. Research company eMarketer this week estimated Google made ­£.billion in ad revenue in the UK last year and will make more than £billion this year. Amazon paid only £million tax on British revenue of £.billion. The Government is attempting to crack down on moving profits to low-tax areas and is planning a  per cent digital service tax. But campaigners say tech giants will always sht profits to tax havens unless governments work with each other.  Fair Tax Mark’s Mr Monaghan said: “In the long term, governments need to get together and rip up the ­international rule book and move toward something called unitary taxation. “Profits would be ­apportioned to each country for tax on the basis of where real economic activity takes place. For Google this would likely see a four to five-fold rise in the corporation tax paid in the UK.”

story: NewsCoronavirus can spread ft which is twice the social distancing limit, study claimsThe published study in journal Emerging Infectious Diseases also found the virus was mainly found on floors, rubbish bins, the soles of shoes and sickbed handrailsShareCommentsByGrace Witherden:,  APR NewsWere all at armsbecause of the pandemic" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A new study has found that people suffering with coronavirus may be able to spread it four metres – twice the distance recommended by the Government in social distancing guidelines.Chinese scientists tested air and surface samples in two hospital wards at the Huoshenshan Hospital in Wuhan, the city where the outbreak began between February  and March . The intensive care ward had  patients and the general ward had  patients with milder symptoms. Scientists measured aerosol transmission - when droplets of the virus are so fine they become suspended and remain airborne for several hours. Results of the experiment by a team from the Academy of Military Sciences in Bejing were published in the journal Emerging Infectious Diseases on Friday.The results confirmed that virus-laden aerosols were mainly concentrated near and downstream from patients at up to four metres, though smaller quantities were found upstream up to two metres away.Since the outbreak, the Government has been advising people to remain two metres apart from each other to prevent the spread of coronavirus.The study found the virus was mostly distributed on floors, computer mice, rubbish bins and sickbed handrails.The study also suggests that the virus can spread on the sole of shoes.

story: NewsHero nurse who came out of retirement to lead coronavirus hospital hit with £ fineDeirdre Barr, , from Derry, left retirement to work at Londons NHS Nightingale emergency coronavirus hospital but found a £ parking ticket stuck to her windscreen on FridayShareCommentsByJilly BeattieAnna MacSwan:,  APR NewsRetired nurse Deirdre Barr" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A nurse who left retirement to take charge of Londonaposs NHS Nightingale hospital was hit with a parking fine while working tirelessly to save coronavirus patients.Deirdre Barr, from Derry, Northern Ireland, was issued with the £ ticket despite a leaflet on her windscreen which showed she was an essential worker.The -year-old was appointed director of operations at the ,-bed emergency field hospital at East Londonaposs Excel centre a month ago, Belfast Live reported.But she was dismayed toto her car after a long sht on Friday, which had been parked in Canary Wharf, to find a penalty notice stuck to her windscreen. “I got to my car after a long day at Nightingale Hospital to find this on my car. Tower Hamlets gave me a parking ticket despite me having a Nightingale NHS leaflet clearly displayed, she explained.Follow the latest coronavirus updates hereSince when was parking enforcement an essential service  Deirdre, who worked for the health service for more than  years, leads a team who have volunteered to look after some of the sickest Covid- patients in the country.  They are contracted to work a minimum of  hours a week, and her family in Ireland believe she could be clocking up even more hours to manage the nursing crews and ensure safety and medical standards are top notch. Her nephew Barry McFarland, from Derry, said that medics like his aunt have been working flat out to save lives. It is disgusting that these agents are going around this area ticketing cars when it’s pretty obvious so many medical staff are working in the area, he said. My aunt and her teams are working around the clock to try to save lives and we are all very proud of them. You can see from the ticket that the parking agent waited for eight minutes before issuing that ticket. The last thing people like my aunt need to be worrying about is parking. They’re flat out working to save lives. I understand my aunt had parked in a designated area near her hotel and then had come back to find she’d been issued with a parking fine. So this has interrupted what she is there to be doing. The medical staff and others working at the Nightingale Hospital shouldn’t have to worry about this sort of thing and I find it disgusting that the local council is prepared to try and get money out of these angels. A spokesperson for the London Borough of Tower Hamlets acknowledged Deirdre has displayed an NHS Nightingale notice but said their workers could not be expected to be familiar with such information. The parking ticket and fine have since be cancelled and Deirdre has now been given a permit council staff can recognise. A spokeswoman for Tower Hamlets Council said: “We have issued more than , permits to allow NHS staff and other key workers to park for free in Tower Hamlets during this crisis. “The vehicle had been unlawfully parked in the Canary Wharf area, . miles from NHS Nightingale, and was not displaying a permit. Our staff had issued a ticket as they would normally with any other vehicle.

story: NewsMy Sister Is Not A Statistic - moving poem is a symbol of coronavirus hopeWe share a version of the beautul poem written by Dorothy Duffy in honour of her sister, who she lost to coronavirus. Listeners flocked to stream it when it was read out on Radio ShareCommentsByPatrick Hill:,  APR NewsDorothy Duffywrote a loving poem to her tragic sister Rose " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAmid the horror of Britain’s ever-rising coronavirus death toll, a beacon of light shone yesterday. Powerful, poignant words in an extraordinary poem written by a woman who lost her sister. When Dorothy Duffy read her tribute to Rose Mitchell on Radio  and Five Live, listeners flocked to stream it. Today we offer this abridged version to keep as a symbol of defiance…. and hope. My sister is not a statistic Tomorrow, when the deathometer of Covid is announced in sonorous tones. While all the time the bodies still mount and curl towards the middle of the curve, my sister will be among those numbers. Among the throwaway lines, the platitudes and lowered eyes, an older person with underlying health conditions. A pitul way to lay rest the bare bones of a le. My sister is not a statistic. Her underlying conditions were love, kindness, belief in the essential goodness of mankind, uproarious laughter. Forgiveness, compassion, a storyteller, a survivor, a comforter, a force of nature and so much more. My sister is not a statistic. She died without the soft touch of a loved one’s hand, the feathered kiss upon her forehead, the muted murmur of familiar family voices gathered round her bed  Without the gentle laughter that comes with memories recalled, evoked from a time that already seems distant, when we were connected by the simplicity of touch, of voice, of presence. My sister is not a statistic. She was a woman who spanned the seven ages, a mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister, friend, aunt, carer, giver. My sister is not a statistic. And so she joins the mounting thousands.  They are not statistics on the deathometer of Covid, they are the wives, mothers, children, fathers, sisters, brothers, the layers of all our loved ones. If she could, believe me when I say, she would hold every last one of your loved ones, croon to and comfort them and say ‘you were loved’.

title: skint woman universal credit sells
story: NewsSkint woman on Universal Credit sells fridge to pay for heating as lockdown hits Dallas Kennedy-Willows currently has just p and is using tealights to save on electricityShareByBeth AbbitKatie Mansfield:,  APR Updated:,  APR News" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A woman on Universal Credit has spoken of her hardship as le in lockdown causes her bills to rise substantially. Dallas Kennedy-Willows, a long-term benefit claimant, usually has her budget down to a fine art but with isolation forcing the -year-old to stay inside her one-bedroom flat she has sold her fridge to pay for her heating.  Usually Dallas spends several hours a day at the library applying for jobs, according to the Manchester Evening News, but a bout of tuberculosis as a child has put her in the vulnerable category leaving her scared to leave the house. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic,  click hereShe says she now has just p and a few items of food to last until her next Universal Credit payment and has struggled to get through to the Department of Work and Pensions to arrange an advance payment. “I have phoned up numerous times. I’m just sat on the settee ringing again and again. “You just get a recorded message then after five minutes on hold it cuts you off. “I was pretty shocked. I’m phoning up about money for food. This is the same number for everyone. “It’s already hard to get through to anyone - I feel so sorry for people having to apply for the first time.” Dallas says she receives £ a month in UC, £ of which is spent on rent. She usually spends around £ a week on heating and electricity and other bills, but says her outgoings have drastically increased since the lockdown began. “Normally I would walk to Oldham, which takes about an hour, spend four hours in the library and come back. That would be five or six hours a day that I’d be out of the flat,” she says. “But now I’m just sitting in a cold flat. It’s like sitting in an old damp jail cell in here. “I don’t watch telly all day, I’ve been trying to do a bit of drawing to break up the monotony.” She adds: “I had to sell the fridge to get £ just to be able to pay for heating because I’m not normally in the flat each day. I’m always at the library and I’m using their heating and electricity. “I couldn’t afford to run the fridge so I sold it. I’ve got a small telly and my wi and that’s it. “At night I have to sit here and for lighting I use tealights. I buy a bag of tealights at the start of the month and use those. “It’s been like that constantly. Just the telly on and using tealights for light. Nobody should be living like this.” She says she cannot afford to run the heating throughout the day and the cold has made her feel ill and has seen her wearing a hat to bed and lots of jumpers in the day.  “I put the heating on for five minutes in the morning to dry clothes and for ten minutesI have a bath. “If you’re already poor you can’t go panic buying. I’ve got p in my purse at the moment.” Dallas says has been living on a diet of porridge and says she has a pizza, some bread, a jar of coffee and a box of eggs to tide her over until her next UC payment.

story: NewsRicky Gervais calls to end grim wet markets thought to be hotbed for coronavirusEXCLUSIVE: The comedian was joined by Paul O’Grady and Philippa Forrester in demanding the end of markets with animals like live reptiles, dead dogs and ratsShareCommentsByAmy Sharpe:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsRicky Gervais warns of risks of wet markets fearing they could spark another pandemic " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAnimal lover Ricky Gervais tonight demanded an immediate end to grim wet markets which are a hotbed for spreading infection. The comedian was horried by the Sunday Mirror’s exclusive snaps of bats, snakes and dogs dumped on a street to be sold in North Sulawesi, Indonesia. Other markets had dead rats next to live reptiles with jaws tied shut. Dead dogs lay on crates holding live cats. Comedian Ricky backed our call for action, saying: “For the sake of people and animals, wildle trade and consumption has to end, now.”The coronavirus is feared to have spread from a market in Wuhan, China.Ricky is backed by fellow star Paul O’Grady, wildle hosts Michaela Strachan and Philippa Forrester and reality star Pete Wicks. Ricky,  said: “We can’t carry on exploiting animals, eating wildle and trashing the planet. The wildle trade and markets have to close, otherwise it will be a case of when, and not , we have another global pandemic.” In a message aimed directly at politicians he added: “How bad does this have to get before you close down Indonesia’s extreme animal markets that pose the exact same risk as the wildle wet markets in Wuhan, China ”  The Huanan Seafood Wholesale market in Wuhan was shut on January  and Shenzhen last week became the first Chinese city to ban consumption and trade of dog and cat meat. But in Indonesia, locals say trade goes on in defiance of orders to close. In Kawangkoan on March , pictures showed reptiles alongside bats. In nearby Tomohon, dogs were bludgeoned, blowtorched and displayed beside bats and butchered snakes.  And the grim scenes were repeated only last week, said the charity Animal Friends Manado Indonesia. Paul O’Grady, , host of For the Love of Dogs, has seen a wet market in Yogyakarta, Indonesia. He said: “I was horried. There were dogs on hooks that have been skinned, cages of live kittens. The cruelty is unbelievable.”  Presenter and producer Philippa, , said: “We’re asking impoverished people to make a huge cultural and economic sht. It isn’t easy for a man who has sold dogs to feed his family to just give up his income, however abhorrent we feel it is, so the support needs to come from the top.” Springwatch host Michaela Strachan, , said: “I have seen the appalling conditions in wild animal markets. It’s shockingly cruel, terryingly unhygienic, unethical and often illegal.The pain and terror animals go through makes me feel sick to my stomach. It’s like something from medieval times.” And TOWIE star Pete Wicks, , who previously saved  dogs from a farm in Korea, added: “There is no culture in cruelty. It needs to be stopped.”

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Brits urged to avoid beaches as Easter heatwave brings C highsThe UK public is being urged to remember lockdown rules as Easter Sunday brings highs of C, although hot temperatures are also set to bring thunder and rain in the afternoonShareCommentsByAnna MacSwan:,  APR NewsPeople wear face masks as they take their daily excercise in Victoria Park " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. title: vulnerable kids parents covid coronavirus
story: NewsCoronavirus: Sick kids parents asked to sign Do Not Resuscitate ordersthey get bugEXCLUSIVE: Shocked parents are askingtheir kids lives are thought not worth saving as most vulnerable are asked to sign dont resuscitate forms amid coronavirus crisisShareCommentsByGrace MacaskillGeraldine McKelvie:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsParents of children such as cancer sufferer Ilhan Ates-Suddes have been asked to sign a Do Not Resuscitate order by their GP" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailParents of vulnerable and sick children are furious after being asked by GPs to sign Do Not Resuscitate orderstheir loved ones catch Covid-. One shocked mum, Margaret Ates-Suddes, whose -year-old son Ilhan has cancer, yesterday branded the le or death request as inhumane. Another enraged mother claims her  year-old son was called directly by their GP surgery to ask to consent to a DNR form. The order instructs medics not to perform CPRa patient stops breathing or their heart stops.The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence had told ­doctors to assess people with learning disabilities, autism or cerebral palsy on a “clinical frailty scale” meaning some would be denied ­hospital treatment. Days later Nice did a U-turn after being ­challenged by disabled charities but there are concerns about how the guidance is being interpreted by GPs. Ilhan, of Scar-borough, North Yorks, has a rare form of cancer called ­fibrosarcoma in his neck and jaw. He has to feed through a tube and has a hole in his throat to breath. Mum Margaret, , says the shock call from her GP ­surgery came “totally out of the blue” this week. She said: “They askedwe wanted a DNRIlhan had to be taken to hospital with coronavirus. “When I ­complained, one GP told me there had been a mistake. But how on earth can someone see an -year-old boy’s age on a computer and think that it is ­responsible behaviour  Ilhan is an oncology patient and this is something we would decide with his consultant at Leeds General Infirmary, where the treatment has been amazing.” She added: “Ilhan has fought cancer for seven years and there’s no way I’m going to let anyone give up on him. “Nobody has the right to decide whether someone is worthy of CPR or not. Ilhan is a fighter, always has been.” There was no one available for ­comment at Ilhan’s surgery, which we have chosen not to name.  A -year-old lad from Colchester, Essex, also ­received a call from his surgery askinghe would agree to the DNA order. The boy, who has ­asthma and the connective tissue disorder Ehlers-Danlos, has a say in his own care plan. His mum said: “The surgery called to askhe had enough asthma packs, then askedhe would agree to a DNR on his notes. He asked them what it meant and when they told him he said, ‘Hell no, I’m only .’ “He is about to sit his A-levels. How can his le be worth nothing  He thinks the Government wants him dead.” Last night the boy’s GP surgery said it was unable to comment due to data protection.Elizabeth John, , of Bridgend, South Wales, also got an apology from her GP surgery after they sent a DNR form. Elizabeth, who has cancer, said: “I was made to feel like I was worthless and a burden to society. But I’m not dying yet.”  Her surgery wrote: “Our letter was poorly worded and did not properly articulate the care and commitment we have for our ­patients. We would like to sincerely apologise.” Mencap Chief Executive Edel Harris said: “These letters from GP surgeries are deeply troubling.They wrongly ­conflate having support needs with frailty and risk people with a learning disability not getting equal access to healthcare and ­potentially dying avoidably. “We are extremely concerned these letters have already forced parents or carers to make potentially le or death decisions.” Labour’s shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth said: “This will already be a hugely worrying time for vulnerable people and their families and being asked to make a decision like this will undoubtedly cause more ­distress for them.

Dr Greene told NBC Miami : “I was just shocked that the judge would take this stance without talking to medical experts and knowing the facts and take it so lightly, take my child from me and not think of the effect on her, her mental and psychological well-being.” She said she usually shares custody with her daughter’s father, Eric Greene, but he filed for temporary sole custody when the pandemic hit. He asked for and received an emergency order due “due to the mother’s signicantly heightened exposure to Covid-,” despite the fact Dr Greene has tested negative to the virus.In his court order, Circuit Judge Bernard Shapiro wrote: “In order to protect the best interests of the minor child, including but not limited to the minor child’s safety and welfare, this Court temporarily suspends the Former We’s timesharing until further Order of Court. The suspension is solely related to the outbreak of Covid-.”Dr Greene, who is an emergency room physician, said she believes this discriminates against health care workers.She said: “I know I’m not alone, first responders, nurses, so many people in this position who, because they’re orced, their children are suffering and theyaposre being told they can’t see them, and it’s just not fair.” She said guidance from the American Medical Association’s position on the issue said frontline physicians should be able to go home to their families and to their children, as long as they take proper precautions. Eric Greene’s attorney told the news sit it was not appropriate to comment on the case. Dr Greene says she is now appealing the ruling. She added: I feel like the family court system now is stressing me almost more than the virus, I mean this is a very stressful time for healthcare professionals.
